citation.article-title: Acidiphilium organovorum sp. nov., an acidophilic heterotroph isolated from a Thiobacillus ferrooxidans culture.

p.s: Description of Acidiphilium organovorum sp. nov.
Acidiphilium organovorum (or.ga.no'vor.um. N. L. n. organum organic, compound; L. v. voro eat, consume; N. L. adj. organovorum organisms which use organic compounds)
Cells are gram-negative, aerobic, mesophilic bacilli or coccobacilli (0.6 by 0.8 to 1.0 μm).
A variety of organic compounds support growth as sole carbon and energy sources.
These include simple sugars, sugar alcohols, carboxylic acids, and amino acids.
No growth occurs on lactose, maltose, cellobiose, or any form of reduced sulfur or iron.
Acetic acid and pyruvic acid completely inhibit cell growth at concentrations of 0.01 and 0.1%, respectively.
Increased growth occurs at glucose concentrations (0.5 to 2.0%) higher than those previously used for culturing other Acidiphilium species (5) .
Nutritional supplements of yeast extract and trace amounts of FeSO4 enhance growth.
Cell doubling times of 2.5 h and cell densities of ≥2 x 1010 cells per ml are obtained in basal salts-glucose medium supplemented with yeast extract and FeSO4.
For growth on solid medium, low amounts (0.5 to 0.8%) of high-purity agarose must be used.
White, glossy colonies ≥2 mm in diameter form in 3 to 4 days.
This bacterium gives positive catalase and negative oxidase reactions.
No endospores are formed, and cells die rapidly at temperatures of ≥50°C.
Susceptible to the antibiotics tetracycline, ampicillin, chloramphenicol, and rifampin.
The G+C content of the DNA is 64 mol%.
Of the bacteria tested, DNA homology studies indicate that A. organovorum is most closely related to A. cryptum.
The type strain of A. organovorum is strain ATCC 43141.
